        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

#Loading the data

  dataset_kinneret = json.load(f) 
with open('../input/lake-kinneret-sea-of-galilee-dead-sea-levels/datastore_search_1') as f:
  dataset_deadsea = json.load(f)

source.cb2f9c9d:
df_kinneret['Kinneret_Level']=df_kinneret['Kinneret_Level'].astype('float64')
df_kinneret["Survey_Date"] = pd.to_datetime(df_kinneret["Survey_Date"], format="%Y%m%dT%H:%M:%S")
plt.figure(figsize=(20,14))
sns.lineplot(x=df_kinneret['Survey_Date'], y=df_kinneret.loc[:,'Kinneret_Level'])
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------#

df_deadsea["Dead Sea Level"]=df_deadsea["מפלס"].astype('float64')
df_deadsea["Survey_Date"] = pd.to_datetime(df_deadsea["תאריך מדידה"], format="%d/%m/%Y")
plt.figure(figsize=(20,14))
sns.lineplot(x=df_deadsea["Survey_Date"], y=df_deadsea.loc[:,"Dead Sea Level"])

When inspecting the datasets we see that they have JSON/dictionary type of format.
Next, we filter out the relevant data.
source.5f2056be: We can notice that the kinneret level fluctuates up and down while the dead sea levels have been decreasing
source.23e8572c:
First we load the databases from the following websites:

Kinneret:
https://data.gov.il/api/3/action/datastore_search?resource_id=2de7b543-e13d-4e7e-b4c8-56071bc4d3c8&limit=99999

Dead Sea:
https://data.gov.il/api/3/action/datastore_search?resource_id=823479b4-4771-43d8-9189-6a2a1dcaaf10&limit=9999

These two sites are already included in the input data of the dataset as datastore_search and datastore_search_1 respectively.
source.5dda07ed:
The Dead Sea column names are in hebrew:

'תאריך מדידה' means survey date

'מפלס' means level

Now we bring the data to a useful format and visualize it
